alert.note: Alert for Mercer; Rock Island (Illinois) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS QuadCities (Eastern Iowa and Northwestern Illinois - Quad Cities)
info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued February 18 at 8:38PM CST until February 18 at 9:30PM CST by NWS QuadCities
info.description: The National Weather Service in the Quad Cities has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Southwestern Rock Island County in northwestern Illinois... Northern Mercer County in northwestern Illinois... Northeastern Henry County in southeastern Iowa... Louisa County in southeastern Iowa... Western Cedar County in east central Iowa... Southeastern Johnson County in east central Iowa... Eastern Washington County in southeastern Iowa... Muscatine County in east central Iowa... * Until 930 PM CST. * At 837 PM CST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from near Wheatland to near Kalona, moving southeast at 35 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts greater than 30 mph. Flash freeze. SOURCE...Radar indicated. Spotter reports. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. * This includes the following highways... Interstate 80 in Iowa between mile markers 236 and 272. Interstate 380 near mile marker 1. Locations impacted include... Iowa City, Muscatine, Aledo, Tipton, West Branch, Wapello, Columbus Junction, Coralville, North Liberty, West Liberty, Wilton, Tiffin, Lone Tree, Winfield, University Heights, Riverside, Fruitland, Viola, Millersburg and Matherville. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. Reduce your speed and turn on your headlights! During snow squalls, the visibility may suddenly drop to near zero in whiteout conditions. Wet roadways will quickly freeze. Black ice will cause roads, bridges and overpasses to become slick and dangerous. Slow down and be prepared for sudden loss of traction.
